Award.AwardTitle: After-School Activities: Identifying Risk and Protective Factors for Community Violence Exposure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Community violence has profound implications for youth development. Youth who are exposed to community violence are at risk for a variety of psychological and behavioral difficulties, including poor academic performance, anxiety, depression, post traumatic stress disorder, and substance abuse. Yet, very little research examines why the impact of community violence exposure varies among children. The goal of this research is to identify the characteristics of after-school activities, within schools, homes, and neighborhoods, that protect adolescents from the adverse effects of community violence. By identifying factors that reduce adolescents' risk for violence exposure, this research can have a broad impact, informing after-school programming for poor, urban youth.

First, Dr. Ceballo will utilize longitudinal data from the Project on Human Development in Chicago Neighborhoods (PHDCN). The PHDCN data was drawn from a random, multiracial sample of 6,228 children and mothers residing in Chicago. PHDCN data will allow Dr. Ceballo to examine the impact of mothers' exposure to community violence on maternal mental health and parenting approaches that can impact children's risk. Second, new survey data will be collected with 500 Latino adolescents. This survey will examine the relations among after-school activity participation, culturally-specific values like familismo (e.g., prioritizing family unity) and parenting approaches on Latino adolescents' violence exposure and psychological well-being. Finally, the third study will recruit a subsample of 100 adolescents to participate in a daily diary study of experiences with community violence. This study addresses one of the greatest limitations in the literature: a reliance on children's retrospective recall of violent events. This study will avoid the biases inherent in participants' recall of traumatic events and will investigate youths' experiences with violence as it occurs, providing unique data about the effects of violence exposure on youth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

After-School Activities: Identifying Risk and Protective Factors for Community Violence Exposure


Exposure to community violence presents a pressing public health crisis in the United States with profound implications for youth’s development. It is well documented that adolescents residing in poverty are subjected to especially high rates of community violence. These experiences include incidents such as seeing someone attacked with a knife, seeing a dead body on the way to school, or being chased by individuals or gangs who threaten physical harm. Perhaps not surprisingly, the highest rates of exposure to community violence are reported among poor, racial/ethnic minority youth. A wealth of research has focused on factors that mitigate the effects of community violence on youth in the aftermath of exposure to violence. However, not all children who live in poor, urban neighborhoods are exposed to equally high levels of community violence, and surprisingly little research has examined the factors that precede or place youth at risk for violence exposure in the first place. Thus, in our study, we examined how adolescents’ participation in after-school activities may place youth at greater or lesser risk of experiencing community violence.

 

The main purpose of our study was to investigate adolescents’ after-school activity involvement as a precursor to community violence exposure with a longitudinal research design. While a preponderance of evidence indicates that adolescents’ participation in structured after-school activities is associated with positive developmental outcomes, we know that Latino youth and youth from low-income families participate in far fewer structured, organized activities compared to their European American and higher-income counterparts. For this reason, we recruited a sample of 416 Latino adolescents attending high schools in Chicago and Detroit and comprehensively assessed their experiences with community violence and after-school activities in home-, school-, and community-based activities. In addition, we examined the culturally-specific value of familismo, a widely-held, Latino cultural value emphasizing a sense of family unity, loyalty, and obligations above individual needs. Specifically, we examined whether familismo serves as a culturally-specific protective factor for urban, Latino youth in dangerous neighborhoods by encouraging youth to spend more time in safer home settings with family members.

 

As expected, our sample of Latino youth residing in Chicago and Detroit neighborhoods reported experiencing high rates of community violence, as both witnesses and victims of violence. Latino adolescent boys reported higher rates of personal victimization compared to Latina adolescent girls. Notably, we found unexpected differences in the types of violence exposure experienced by Latino adolescent boys and girls. Latina adolescent girls in our sample reported neighborhood gender-based harassment incidents at rates comparable to Latino adolescent males’ reporting of community violence incidents. Greater exposure to all forms of violence was associated with more symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Moreover, our findings revealed that the magnitude of association between gender-based harassment and PTSD symptoms was quite strong. Indeed, the effect of gender-based harassment on PTSD symptoms was more than six times larger than the effect of personal victimization and more than ten times larger than the effect of witnessing violence. This was an unexpected, extremely important finding, indicating that gender-based harassment is not only prevalent in neighborhoods but is commonly encountered by Latino youth. Thus, future research on community violence should incorporate measures of gender-based harassment in order to fully capture the experiences and impact of neighborhood violence on youth.

 

Furthermore, our results found that only familismo endorsement, not home-based activities, was associated with lower violence exposure, measured concurrently. Greater endorsement of familismo was related to less personal victimization concurrently, but not one year later when also accounting for prior violence exposure. This suggests that the protective association between familismo and less violence exposure is not due to a higher frequency of participating in safer home-based activities. Instead, familismo may reflect a culturally appropriate balance of parental monitoring and supervision of adolescent activities.

 

In keeping with our original questions about after-school activities, our findings demonstrate that the specific characteristics of community-based activities do matter. Non-structured community-based activities, for example “hanging out” with friends or playing pick-up sports games, were associated with higher rates of witnessing violence and personal victimization both concurrently and one year later. In contrast, similar results were not found with structured community-based activities that were facilitated by an organization with adult supervision and guidelines for participation. Hence, our findings help identify the characteristics of after-school activities that increase the risk for violence exposure and lend support for the development of structured, well-supervised activities for youth in poor, high-crime neighborhoods. We have presented our findings to audiences at national academic conferences as well as groups of parents, teachers, and staff in our participating high schools. Although financial budget constraints often lead to cutting extracurricular opportunities for youth, our results add to the growing base of evidence against such cuts.
